ray.rage.game

Class BaseGame

  • java.lang.Object
    • ray.rage.game.AbstractGame
      • ray.rage.game.BaseGame
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.event.KeyListener, java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener, java.awt.event.MouseWheelListener, java.util.EventListener, Manageable, Game
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    VariableFrameRateGame

    public abstract class BaseGame
extends AbstractGame
implements java.awt.event.KeyListener, java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener, java.awt.event.MouseWheelListener
    The base game provides a base implementation for the mayority of a game's behavior during setup, teardown, and the proper sequence to follow. It's a convenience to allow users to get "up and running" more quickly.

    Due to different possibilities in how a main loop might be implemented (e.g. variable vs fixed frame rates), this base implementation does not contain a main-loop. In other words, this class is loop-agnostic.

    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera
    See Also:
    VariableFrameRateGame

      • setupWindowViewports

        protected void setupWindowViewports(RenderWindow rw)
        Description copied from class: AbstractGame
        This is where the game logically divides a render-window's real-estate into viewports. Most render-windows only need one (default).
        Specified by:
        setupWindowViewports in class AbstractGame
        Parameters:
        rw - The render-window having its viewports set up.
